newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares edge down, seen up after breather.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares edge down, seen up after breather.

text.p: Leading Russian shares edged down on Wednesday as local brokers took profits and foreign buyers stayed out of the market, but some traders said prices would rise after a few days' breather.
The Russian Trading System index of 24 shares fell by 2.03 percent to 186.14 on $22.57 million in volume.
"Prices have been falling all day," said Alexei Genkin, manager of international sales at IK Alfa-Capital.
"There were practically no international buyers. Russian brokers understood that they had nothing else to wait for and started taking profits."
Nick Mokhoff of Alliance-Menatep said prices would fluctuate in a two to three percent range over the next few days.
Dealers said western investors had cheered news that President Boris Yeltsin would undergo a heart operation in mid-November, earlier than some estimates.
Genkin predicted that an American Depositary Share issue for natural gas monopoly Gazprom, due shortly, would be oversubscribed and drive the market up.

Gazprom plans to make an ADRs issue and its lead managers said last week that the preliminary price for the international offering will be between $14.00 and $16.00. One ADS covers ten ordinary shares.
"Real investors will continue holding Russian shares," Genkin said.
"They believe in Russia and for them there is no sense to leave the market now."
Truck maker KamAZ was among the losers of the day after the government decided to start bankruptcy cases against the company for alleged tax evasion, he added.

KamAZ fell to $1.23 from $1.30 at Tuesday's close, LUKoil edged down to $10.26 from $10.47, Rostelekom dropped to $2.66 after 2.73, UES fell to $0.0823 from $0.0837 and Norilsk Nickel ticked down to $6.25 after $6.26.
